poem:
Title: A Rhetoric in Politics

A plume of newsprint -
unfurled in morning light.
Rachel, rendered in ink, rebukes
Thatcher's promise of revival.

Academic apparitions whisper,
"Richard Tice, painted in far-right hues,
unfurls threats of defamation."

Yet, in the quiet language of law,
there is no solid ground.
Merely the slippery slide
of semantics -
a dance of words,
footprints left in the
murmuring drift of public discourse.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Rachel Reeves criticised over ‘Thatcher’s decade of renewal’ comments – UK politics live 2.59pm GMT An academic who specialises in media law has been in touch to say that Richard Tice was wrong to claim that calling Reform UK “far-right” would be defamatory. (See 11.36am.) He explains: Richard Tice’s assertion that labelling Reform UK “far-right” is defamatory, and in particular his threat to involve lawyers against those repeating the statement, has no basis in law.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
